question_content.barrons:question: During the years 1933–1936, American foreign policy may best be described as a policy of
question_content.barrons:explanation:
deliberate noninvolvement.

Despite their indignation against the Third Reich’s outrages during the years 1933–1936, Americans generally favored isolationist policies and neutrality, as witnessed by the Neutrality Acts of 1935 and 1936. Thus, American foreign policy during the period may best be described as a policy of deliberate noninvolvement or nonintervention.

Overt belligerence is incorrect. In the early to mid-1930s, American foreign policy favored isolationist policies and neutrality, not overt belligerence (openly warlike hostility).

Moral indignation is incorrect. While there was great indignation in America at the Third Reich’s actions, American foreign policy was not one of moral indignation.

Opportunistic profiteering is incorrect. The Neutrality Acts of 1935 and 1936 demonstrated that America’s foreign policy was to stand by its principles and refuse to trade with the belligerent nations. Thus, American foreign policy in the period was not one of opportunistic profiteering.

Covert collusion is incorrect. It was not American foreign policy to engage in covert collusion (hidden conspiracy) with the forces of the Third Reich.
